decks.notes: Utilize Eldrazi creatures and powerful control spells to disrupt opponents while ramping up towards casting Emrakul, the Promised End. Use cards like Kozilek's Return and All Is Dust to clear the board, while Ancient Stirrings and Utopia Sprawl help find key pieces. Malevolent Rumble can also help control the board, while World Breaker provides a versatile threat. The deck aims to overwhelm opponents with large Eldrazi creatures while maintaining control of the game through a mix of removal and disruption spells.

The main concept of this Eldrazi Control deck is to utilize Eldrazi creatures and powerful control spells to dominate the battlefield. The deck focuses on ramping up mana quickly, utilizing cards like Utopia Sprawl and Talisman of Impulse to cast huge threats like Emrakul, the Promised End and World Breaker. The deck also includes control elements like Kozilek's Command and Malevolent Rumble to disrupt the opponent's strategy. By combining ramp, control, and high-power threats, this deck aims to overwhelm the opponent and secure victory.

This deck focuses on aggressive play by utilizing low-cost creatures and powerful burn spells to quickly overwhelm the opponent. The key strategy is to establish board presence early with efficient creatures like Ragavan, Nimble Pilferer and Amped Raptor, while disrupting the opponent's game plan with cards like Blood Moon and Static Prison. The deck also includes ways to protect its creatures and generate additional value through cards like Goblin Bombardment and Guide of Souls. By combining fast creatures and disruptive elements, the deck aims to dominate the battlefield and finish off the opponent swiftly.

This deck focuses on quickly filling up the graveyard with cards like Burning Inquiry, Goblin Lore, and Mishra's Bauble to get out large creatures like Hollow One and Nethergoyf. Detective's Phoenix and Dragon's Rage Channeler help to keep up the pressure while cards like Lightning Bolt and Lava Dart offer direct damage to finish off opponents. The key strategy is to overwhelm opponents with high-powered creatures and aggressive plays, utilizing the graveyard as a valuable resource for fueling the deck's threats.

This deck focuses on setting up a powerful combo by cycling through creatures and ultimately casting Living End to bring them back onto the battlefield. It utilizes cards like Street Wraith and Curator of Mysteries to cycle through the deck quickly, while also controlling the opponent's board with cards like Endurance and Subtlety. The key strategy is to overwhelm the opponent with a large number of creatures reanimated from the graveyard, while also having access to countermagic like Force of Negation for protection.

This Mardu Aggro deck focuses on utilizing powerful creatures and burn spells to quickly overwhelm opponents. The inclusion of Jegantha, the Wellspring as a companion provides an additional source of mana acceleration. The deck also includes disruptive cards like Thoughtseize and Fatal Push to control the board, while creatures like Ajani, Nacatl Pariah and Amped Raptor provide strong attacking options. The mana base is designed to support the deck's aggressive strategy, with a mix of lands that produce different colors of mana to ensure the deck can play its spells efficiently.

This deck focuses on using control elements to protect and ramp into powerful Eldrazi creatures like Emrakul, the Aeons Torn and Ulamog, the Defiler. The deck utilizes cards like All Is Dust and Through the Breach to disrupt opponents while establishing a strong board presence with Eldrazi Temple and Grove of the Burnwillows. The goal is to quickly ramp into the big Eldrazi threats and overwhelm the opponent with powerful creatures and disruptive spells. The deck also includes support cards like Kozilek's Command and Boseiju, Who Endures to further support its control strategy.

The deck focuses on quickly dumping cards into the graveyard to take advantage of the graveyard interaction of cards like Hollow One and Dragon's Rage Channeler. By using cards like Mishra's Bauble and Goblin Lore, the deck aims to fill the graveyard with cheap spells to cast Hollow One for free, while also utilizing aggro creatures like Detective's Phoenix and Nethergoyf to apply early pressure. The deck also includes disruptive spells like Fatal Push and Lightning Bolt to deal with threats and maintain board control, leading to a fast and aggressive gameplay style.

This Modern deck focuses on a fast-paced aggressive strategy that revolves around gaining life through effects like Martyr of Sands and Abiding Grace, while disrupting the opponent's game plan with cards like Ranger-Captain of Eos and Skyclave Apparition. The deck also includes control elements like Supreme Verdict and Temporary Lockdown to maintain board presence. Additionally, the use of Ephemerate and Emeria, the Sky Ruin provides value and recursion to outgrind opponents in longer games. The deck aims to overwhelm the opponent with a combination of aggro, disruption, and incremental life gain.

The main focus of this deck is to assemble the UrzaTron lands (Urza's Tower, Mine, Power Plant) to generate a large amount of mana and cast powerful Eldrazi creatures like Ulamog and Thought-Knot Seer. The deck also utilizes control elements such as Karn, the Great Creator and All Is Dust to disrupt the opponent's strategy, while utilizing ramp cards like Expedition Map and Eldrazi Temple to accelerate the mana production. The goal is to overwhelm the opponent with big threats and disruption while maintaining control of the game.

The deck focuses on aggressive Boros strategies to overwhelm the opponent quickly. It utilizes efficient creatures like Guide of Souls, Ragavan, and Phlage, supported by removal spells like Lightning Bolt and Galvanic Discharge. The inclusion of cards like Blood Moon and Static Prison disrupt the opponent's game plan while Ajani, Nacatl Pariah provides additional ways to finish off the opponent. The deck aims to apply early pressure, control the board with disruptive elements, and close out the game swiftly.
